ControlledConcept.gml:description: Geologic environments on the surface of the solid Earth. Hierarchy presented here is based on assumption that a particular setting may be specified by a combination of a climatic setting with one or more process or geomorphically defined settings.. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:earth_surface_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Earth surface setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by absence of direct marine influence. Most of the subaerial settings are also terrestrial, but lacustrine settings, while terrestrial, are not subaerial, so the subaerial settings are not included as subcategories. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:terrestrial_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Terrestrial setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The usually dry and nearly level plain that occupies the lowest parts of closed depressions, such as those occurring on intermontane basin floors. Temporary flooding occurs primarily in response to precipitation-runoff events. Source: Based on Hawley and Parsons, 1980
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:playa_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Playa setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting associated with a lake. Always overlaps with terrestrial, may overlap with subarial, subaqueous, or shoreline. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lacustrine_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Lacustrine setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The low, nearly flat, alluvial tract of land at or near the mouth of a river, commonly forming a triangular or fan-shaped plain of considerable area, crossed by many distributaries of the main river, perhaps extending beyond the general trend of the lake shore, resulting from the accumulation of sediment supplied by the river in such quantities that it is not removed by waves or currents. Most deltas are partly subaerial and partly below water. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lacustrine_delta
ControlledConcept.name: lacustrine delta

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by gentle surface slope, and at least intermittent presence of standing water, which may be fresh, brackish, or saline. Wetland may be terrestrial setting or shoreline setting. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:wetland_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Wetland setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A water-saturated, periodically wet or continually flooded area with the surface not deeply submerged, essentially without the formation of peat. Marshes are characterized by sedges, cattails, rushes, or other aquatic and grasslike vegetation. Swamps are characterized by tree and brush vegetation. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005; Soil Science Society of America, 1997.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:swamp_or_marsh_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Swamp or marsh setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Waterlogged, spongy ground, consisting primarily of mosses, containing acidic, decaying vegetation that may develop into peat. Source: Jackson, 1997; NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:bog
ControlledConcept.name: Bog

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A desert plain strewn with wind-abraded pebbles, or gibbers; a gravelly desert. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:gibber_plain
ControlledConcept.name: gibber plain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Geologic setting dominated by a river system; river plains may occur in any climatic setting. Includes active channels, abandoned channels, levees, oxbow lakes, flood plain. May be part of an alluvial plain that includes terraces composed of abandoned river plain deposits. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:river_plain_system_setting
ControlledConcept.name: River plain system setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The bed where a natural body of surface water flows or may flow; a natural passageway or depression of perceptible extent containing continuously or periodically flowing water, or forming a connecting link between two bodies of water; a watercourse Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:river_channel
ControlledConcept.name: River channel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A stream that divides into or follows an interlacing or tangled network of several small branching and reuniting shallow channels separated from each other by ephemeral branch islands or channel bars, resembling in plan the strands of a complex braid. Such a stream is generally believed to indicate an inability to carry all of its load, such as an overloaded and aggrading stream flowing in a wide channel on a floodplain Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:braided_channel
ControlledConcept.name: braided channel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Produced by a mature stream swinging from side to side as it flows across its floodplain or shifts its course laterally toward the convex side of an original curve Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:meandering_channel
ControlledConcept.name: meandering channel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A drainage channel along which runoff no longer occurs, as on an alluvial fan Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:abandoned_channel
ControlledConcept.name: abandoned channel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The abandoned, bow- or horseshoe-shaped channel of a former meander, left when the stream formed a cutoff across a narrow meander neck. Note that these are typically lakes, thus also lacustrine. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:cutoff_meander
ControlledConcept.name: cutoff meander

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The surface or strip of relatively smooth land adjacent to a river channel, constructed by the present river in its existing regimen and covered with water when the river overflows its banks. It is built of alluvium carried by the river during floods and deposited in the sluggish water beyond the influence of the swiftest current. A river has one floodplain and may have one or more terraces representing abandoned floodplains Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:floodplain
ControlledConcept.name: floodplain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Location on gentle slope at the foot of a mountain; generally used in terms of intermontane-basin terrain. Main components include: (a) An erosional surface on bedrock adjacent to the receding mountain front (pediment, rock pediment); (b) A constructional surface comprising individual alluvial fans and interfan valleys, also near the mountain front; and (c) A distal complex of coalescent fans (bajada), and alluvial slopes without fan form. Piedmont slopes grade to basin-floor depressions with alluvial and temporary lake plains or to surfaces associated with through drainage. Source: Hawley and Parsons, 1980+F98
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:piedmont_slope_system_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Piedmont slope system setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A low, outspread, relatively flat to gently sloping mass of loose rock material, shaped like an open fan or a segment of a cone, deposited by a stream (esp. in a semiarid region) at the place where it issues from a narrow mountain valley upon a plain or broad valley, or where a tributary stream is near or at its junction with the main stream, or wherever a constriction in a valley abruptly ceases or the gradient of the stream suddenly decreases; it is steepest near the mouth of the valley where its apex points upstream, and it slopes gently and convexly outward with gradually decreasing gradient Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:alluvial_fan
ControlledConcept.name: Alluvial fan

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An assemblage landforms produced by alluvial and fluvial processes (braided streams, terraces, etc.,) that form low gradient, regional ramps along the flanks of mountains and extend great distances from their sources (e.g., High Plains of North America). (NRCS GLOSSARY OF LANDFORM AND GEOLOGIC TERMS). A level or gently sloping tract or a slightly undulating land surface produced by extensive deposition of alluvium... Synonym-- wash plain;...river plain; aggraded valley plain;... (Jackson, 1997, p. 17). May include one or more River plain systems. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:alluvial_plain
ControlledConcept.name: Alluvial plain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A gently sloping erosional surface developed at the foot of a receding hill or mountain slope. The surface may be essentially bare, exposing earth material that extends beneath adjacent uplands; or it may be thinly mantled with alluvium and colluvium, ultimately in transit from upland front to basin or valley lowland. In hill-foot slope terrain the mantle is designated "pedisediment." The term has been used in several geomorphic contexts: Pediments may be classed with respect to (a) landscape positions, for example, intermontane-basin piedmont or valley-border footslope surfaces (respectively, apron and terrace pediments (Cooke and Warren, 1973)); (b) type of material eroded, bedrock or regolith; or (c) combinations of the above. Compare - Piedmont slope.. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004; NRCS, 2001
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:pediment_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Pediment setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting depleted in oxygen, typically subaqueous. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:anoxic_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Anoxic setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Marine environment in which carbonate sediment does not dissolve before reaching the sea floor and can accumulate. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:above_carbonate_compensation_depth_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Above carbonate compensation depth setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Marine environment in which water is deep enough that carbonate sediment goes into solution before it can accumulate on the sea floor. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:below_carbonate_compensation_depth_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Below carbonate compensation depth setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting situated in or under permanent, standing water. Used for marine and lacustrine settings, but not for fluvial settings. Source: based on NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:subaqueous_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Subaqueous setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting at the interface between the solid earth and the atmosphere, includes some shallow subaqueous settings in river channels and playas. Characterized by conditions and processes, such as erosion, that exist or op.erate in the open air on or immediately adjacent to the land surface Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:subaerial_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Subaerial setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary setting in which wind is the dominant process producing, transporting, and depositing sediment. Typically has low-relief plain or piedmont slope physiography. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:aeolian_process_setting
ControlledConcept.name: aeolian process setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Extensive deposits on sand in an area where the supply is abundant. As a characteristic, individual dunes somewhat resemble barchans but are highly irregular in shape and crowded; erg areas of the Sahara are an example. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:dunefield
ControlledConcept.name: dunefield

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A sand-covered plain dominated by aeolian processes. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:sand_plain
ControlledConcept.name: sand plain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by mean annual precipitation of 10 inches (25 cm) or less. (Jackson, 1997, p. 172). Equivalent to SLTT 'Desert setting', but use 'Arid' to emphasize climatic nature of setting defintion. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:arid_or_semi_arid_environment_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Arid or Semi Arid environment setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting with hot, humid climate influenced by equatorial air masses, no winter season. Source: ecounits (Cleland et al., 1997)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:humid_tropical_climatic_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Humid tropical climatic setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting with seasonal climate having hot to cold or humid to arid seasons. Source: ecounits (Cleland et al., 1997)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:humid_temperate_climatic_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Humid temperate climatic setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting with climate dominated by temperatures below the freezing temperature of water. Includes polar deserts because precipitation is generally scant at high latitude. Climate controlled by arctic air masses, cold dry enviornment with short summer. Source: ecounits (Cleland et al., 1997)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:polar_climatic_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Polar climatic setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Geologic settings characterized by location adjacent to the ocean, or a lake. A strip of land of indefinite width (may be many kilometers), bordering a body of water that extends from the water line inland to the first major change in landform features. Marine or non-marine not specified. Includes settings that may be subarial or subaqueous, but are intrinsically associated with the interface between land areas and water bodies.. Source: based on Neuendorf et al, 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:shoreline_settings
ControlledConcept.name: Shoreline settings

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The unconsolidated material at the shoreline that covers a gently sloping zone, typically with a concave profile, extending landward from the low-water line to the place where there is a definite change in material or physiographic form (such as a cliff), or to the line of permanent vegetation (usually the effective limit of the highest storm waves); at the shore of a body of water, formed and washed by waves or tides, usually covered by sand or gravel, and lacking a bare rocky surface. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:beach
ControlledConcept.name: beach

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A narrow, elongate sand or gravel ridge rising slightly above the high-tide level and extending generally parallel with the shore, but separated from it by a lagoon (Shepard, 1954, p.1904), estuary, or marsh; it is extended by longshore transport and is rarely more than several kilometers long. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:barrier_beach
ControlledConcept.name: barrier beach

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Settings characterized by very low surface slope and proximity to shoreline. Generally within peritidal setting, but characterized by low surface gradients and generally low-energy sedimentary processes. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:low_energy_shoreline_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Low energy shoreline setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Modern "algal flats are found on rock or mud in areas flooded only by the highest tides and are often subject to high evaporation rates. Algal flats survive only when an area is salty enough to eliminate snails and other herbivorous animals that eat algae, yet is not so salty that the algae cannot survive. The most common species of algae found on algal flats are blue-green algae of the genera Scytonema and Schizothrix. These algae can tolerate the daily extremes in temperature and oxygen that typify conditions on the flats. Other plants sometimes found on algal flats include one-celled green algae, flagellates, diatoms, bacteria, and isolated scrubby red and black mangroves, as well as patches of saltwort. Animals include false cerith, cerion snails, fiddler crabs, and great land crabs. Flats with well developed algal mats are restricted for the most part to the Keys, with Sugarloaf and Crane Keys offering prime examples of algal flat habitat." (Audubon, 1991) Source: http://www.audubonofflorida.org/main/wetlands/chp3.htm; Reading, 1978
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:algal_flat_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Algal flat setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A relatively level area of fine grained material (e.g. silt) along a shore (as in a sheltered estuary or chenier-plain) or around an island, alternately covered and uncovered by the tide or covered by shallow water, and barren of vegetation. Includes most tidal flats, but lacks denotation of tidal influence.. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004; Jackson, 1997
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:mud_flat_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Mud flat setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by arid to semi-arid conditions on restricted coastal plains mostly above normal high tide level, with evaporite-saline mineral, tidal-flood, and eolian deposits. Boundaries with intertidal setting and non-tidal terrestrial setting are gradational. (Jackson, 1997, p. 561). Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004; based on Jackson 1997; Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:marginal_marine_sabkha_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Marginal marine sabkha setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Pertaining to the shore area marginal to the littoral zone, just above high-tide level Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:supratidal
ControlledConcept.name: supratidal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: setting meant to include all the various geographic elements typically associated with a barrier island coastline, including the barrier islands, and geomorphic/geographic elements that are linked by processes associated with the presence of the island (e.g. wash over fans, inlet channel, back barrier lagoon). Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:barrier_island_coastline_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Barrier island coastline setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A lagoon that is roughly parallel to the coast and is separated from the open ocean by a strip of land or by a barrier reef. Tidal influence is typically restricted and the lagoon is commonly hypersaline. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:barrier_lagoon
ControlledConcept.name: barrier lagoon

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A low relief plain bordering a water body extending inland to the nearest elevated land, sloping very gently towards the water body. Distinguished from alluvial plain by presence of relict shoreline-related deposits or morphology. Source: based on Neuendorf et al, 2005, p. 125
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:coastal_plain_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Coastal plain setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A shoreline setting in which terrigineous input is minor compared to local carbonate sediment production. Constructional biogenic activity is an important element in geomorphic development. Source: this vocabulary+F82
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:carbonate_dominated_shoreline_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate dominated shoreline setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A shallow stretch of salt or brackish water, partly or completely separated from a sea or lake by an offshore reef, barrier island, sand or spit (Jackson, 1997). Water is shallow, tidal and wave-produced effects on sediments; strong light reaches sediment.. Source: generalize from Jackson 1997 and NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lagoonal_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Lagoonal setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Shoreline with significant relief and abundant rock outcrop. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:rocky_coast_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Rocky coast setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A dune field on low-lying land recently abandoned or built up by the sea; the dunes may ascend a cliff and travel inland. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:coastal_dune_field
ControlledConcept.name: coastal dune field

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Pertaining to the benthic ocean environment or depth zone between high water and low water; also, pertaining to the organisms of that environment Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:intertidal
ControlledConcept.name: Intertidal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting subject to tidal processes Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:tidal_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Tidal setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An extensive, nearly horizontal, barren tract of land that is alternately covered and uncovered by the tide, and consisting of unconsolidated sediment (mostly mud and sand). It may form the top surface of a deltaic deposit. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:tidal_flat_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Tidal flat setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A marsh bordering a coast (as in a shallow lagoon or sheltered bay), formed of mud and of the resistant mat of roots of salt-tolerant plants, and regularly inundated during high tides; a marshy tidal flat. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:tidal_marsh
ControlledConcept.name: tidal marsh

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A major channel followed by the tidal currents, extending from offshore into a tidal marsh or a tidal flat. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:tidal_channel
ControlledConcept.name: tidal channel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Environments at the seaward end or the widened funnel-shaped tidal mouth of a river valley where fresh water comes into contact with seawater and where tidal effects are evident (adapted from Glossary of Geology, Jackson, 1997, p. 217). Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:estuary_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Estuary setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A lagoon produced by the temporary sealing of a river estuary by a storm barrier. Such lagoons are usually seasonal and exist until the river breaches the barrier; they occur in regions of low or spasmodic rainfall Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:estuarine_lagoon
ControlledConcept.name: estuarine lagoon

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A delta that has filled, or is in the process of filling, an estuary Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:estuarine_delta
ControlledConcept.name: estuarine delta

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by location under the surface of the sea. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;; Webster's Encyclopedic Unabridged Dictionary of the English Language, 2001, p. 1894.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:marine_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Marine setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The deepest oceanic environment, i.e., over 6,000 m in depth. Always in deep sea trench. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:hadal
ControlledConcept.name: hadal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at water depths between 3,500 and 6,000 metres Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:abyssal
ControlledConcept.name: abyssal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at water depths between 200 and 3500 metres Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:bathyal
ControlledConcept.name: bathyal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at water depths between 200 and 600 metres Source: Berggren, W.A. & Miller, K.G., 1989. Cenozoic bathyal and abyssal calcareous benthic foraminiferal zonation. Micropalaeontology 35, 308-320
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:upper_bathyal
ControlledConcept.name: upper bathyal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at water depths between 600 and 1000 metres Source: Berggren, W.A. & Miller, K.G., 1989. Cenozoic bathyal and abyssal calcareous benthic foraminiferal zonation. Micropalaeontology 35, 308-320
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:middle_bathyal
ControlledConcept.name: middle bathyal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at depths between 1000 and 3500 metres Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E., Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.; Berggren, W.A. & Miller, K.G., 1989. Cenozoic bathyal and abyssal calcareous benthic foraminiferal zonation. Micropalaeontology 35, 308-320
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lower_bathyal
ControlledConcept.name: lower bathyal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at depths between low-tide level and 200 metres, or between low-tide level and approximately the edge of the continental shelf Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:neritic
ControlledConcept.name: neritic

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at depths between 30 and 100 metres Source: this vocabulary JL
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:middle_neritic
ControlledConcept.name: middle neritic

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at depths between 100 and 200 metres or between low-tide level and approximately the edge of the continental shelf Source: this vocabulary JL
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:outer_neritic
ControlledConcept.name: outer neritic

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ocean environment at depths between low tide level and 30 metres Source: this vocabulary JL
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:inner_neritic
ControlledConcept.name: inner neritic

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A ridgelike or moundlike structure, layered or massive, built by sedentary calcareous organisms, esp. corals, and consisting mostly of their remains; it is wave-resistant and stands topographically above the surrounding contemporaneously deposited sediment. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:biological_reef_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Biological reef setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The seaward side of a reef; the slope covered with deposits of coarse reef talus Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:forereef
ControlledConcept.name: forereef

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A stony platform of Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:reef_flat
ControlledConcept.name: reef flat

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The landward side of a reef. The term is often used adjectivally to refer to deposits within the restricted lagoon behind a barrier reef, such as the "back-reef facies" of lagoonal deposits. In some places, as on a platform-edge reef tract, "back reef" refers to the side of the reef away from the open sea, even though no land may be nearby Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:backreef
ControlledConcept.name: backreef

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Deep ocean basin with steep (average 10 degrees) slope toward land, more gentle slope (average 5 degrees) towards the sea, and abundant seismic activity on landward side of trench. Does not denote water depth, but may be very deep. Source: Reading, 1978
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:deep_sea_trench
ControlledConcept.name: Deep sea trench

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Near flat areas of ocean floor, slope less than 1:1000; generally receive only distal turbidite and pelagic sediments. Source: Bates & Jackson, 1987; Heezen & Laughton, 1963; Reading, 1978, p. 390
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:basin_plain_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Basin plain setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The part of a subaqueous basin that is between a bordering shelf setting, which separate the basin from an adjacent landmass, and a very low-relief basin plain setting. Source: based on NADM SLTTs, 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:slope_rise_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Slope-rise setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Large fan-shaped cones of sediment on the ocean floor, generally associated with submarine canyons that provide sediment supply to build the fan.. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:submarine_fan_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Submarine fan setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "That part of the ocean floor that is between the shoreline and the continental slope (or, when there is no noticeable continental slope, a depth of 200 m). It is characterized by its gentle slope of 0.1 degree" (Jackson, 1997, p. 138). Continental shelves have a classic shoreline-shelf-slope profile termed 'clinoform'. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:continental_shelf_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Continental shelf setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "An area of the continental margin between the shoreline and the continental slope that is topographically more complex than the continental shelf. It is characterized by ridges and basins, some of which are below the depth of the continental shelf. An example is the southern California continental borderland;...." (Jackson, 1997, p. 138).. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:continental_borderland_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Continental borderland setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A shallow submerged plateau separated from the continental landmass, on which high biological carbonate production rates produce enough sediment to maintain the platform surface near sea level. Grades into atoll as area becomes smaller and ringing coral reefs become more prominent part of the setting. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:marine_carbonate_platform_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Marine carbonate platform setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Marine setting situated within the interior of the continent, rather than at the edge of a continent. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:epicontinental_marine_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Epicontinental marine setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Broad category for subaqueous marine settings characterized by significant relief above adjacent sea floor. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:ocean_highland_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Ocean highland setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Ocean highland associated with a divergent continental margin (spreading center). Setting is characterized by active volcanism, locally steep relief, hydrothermal activity, and pelagic sedimentation. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:mid_ocean_ridge_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Mid ocean ridge setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Region of elevated ocean crust that commonly rises to within 2-3 km of thre surface above an abyssal sea floor that lies several km deeper. Climate and water depths are such that a marine carbonate platform does not develop. Source: Reading, 1978
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:oceanic_plateau_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Oceanic plateau setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting that consists of a conical mountain on the ocean floor (guyot). Typically characterized by active volcanism, pelagic sedimentation. If the mountain is high enough to reach the photic zone, carbonate production may result in reef building to produce a carbonate platform or atoll setting. Source: Reading, 1978+F63
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:seamount_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Seamount setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Environments at the mouth of a river or stream that enters a standing body of water (ocean or lake). The delta forms a triangular or fan-shaped plain of considerable area. Subaerial parts of the delta are crossed by many distributaries of the main river, and commonly extend beyond the general trend of the coast. Subaqueous parts of the delta merge with the adjacent basin floor, and are progressively influenced by non-fluvial processes. Deltas result from the accumulation of sediment supplied by the river in such quantities that it is not removed by tides, waves, and currents. Adapted from the Glossary of Geology definition for delta (Jackson, 1997, p. 167). Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:deltaic_system_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Deltaic system setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The part of a delta that is below the effective depth of wave erosion, lying beyond the delta front, and sloping gently down to the floor of the basin into which the delta is advancing and where clastic river sediment ceases to be a significant part of the basin-floor deposits; it is entirely below the water level Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:prodelta
ControlledConcept.name: prodelta

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A narrow zone where deposition in deltas is most active, consisting of a continuous sheet of sand, and occurring within the effective depth of wave erosion (10 m or less). It is the zone separating the Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:delta_front
ControlledConcept.name: delta front

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A divergent stream flowing away from the main stream and not returning to it, as in a delta or on an alluvial plain Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:distributary_channel
ControlledConcept.name: distributary channel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The mouth of a delta distributary channel where fluvial discharge moves from confined to unconfined flow conditions Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:distributary_mouth
ControlledConcept.name: distributary mouth

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A pronounced indentation of the delta front between advancing stream distributaries, occupied by shallow water, and either open to the sea or partly enclosed by minor distributaries Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:interdistributary_bay
ControlledConcept.name: interdistributary bay

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The level or nearly level surface composing the landward part of a large or compound delta; strictly, an alluvial plain characterized by repeated channel bifurcation and divergence, multiple distributary channels, and interdistributary flood basins Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:delta_plain
ControlledConcept.name: delta plain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The part of a delta plain which is penetrated by saline water and is subject to tidal processes Source: Reading, H.G. & Collinson, J.D., 1996. Clastic coasts. 154-231 in Reading, H.G. (ed.), Sedimentary Environments: Processses, Facies and Stratigraphy, third edition. Blackwell Science, Oxford
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lower_delta_plain
ControlledConcept.name: lower delta plain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The part of a delta plain essentially unaffected by basinal processes. They do not differ substantially from alluvial environments except that areas of swamp, marsh and lakes are usually more widespread and channels may bifurcate downstream Source: Reading, H.G. & Collinson, J.D., 1996. Clastic coasts. 154-231 in Reading, H.G. (ed.), Sedimentary Environments: Processses, Facies and Stratigraphy, third edition. Blackwell Science, Oxford
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:upper_delta_plain
ControlledConcept.name: upper delta plain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Earth surface setting with geography defined by spatial relationship to glaciers (e.g. on top of a glacier, next to a glacier, in front of a glacier...). Processes related to moving ice dominate sediment transport and deposition and landform development. Includes subaqueous, shoreline, and terrestrial settings that are impacted by the presence of glaciers. Considered a geographically defined setting in that a glacier is a geographic feature. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:glacier_related_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Glacier related setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Contained, embedded, or carried within the body of a glacier or ice sheet; said of meltwater streams, till, drift, moraine Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:englacial_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Englacial setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Immediately in front of or just beyond the outer limits of a glacier or ice sheet, generally at or near its lower end; said of lakes, streams, deposits, and other features produced by or derived from the glacier ice Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:proglacial_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Proglacial setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Settings adjacent to edges of confined glacier. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:glacier_lateral_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Glacier lateral setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Region of sediment deposition due to melting of glacier ice. ablation and flow till setting. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:glacier_terminus_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Glacier terminus setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formed or accumulated in or by the bottom parts of a glacier or ice sheet; said of meltwater streams, till, moraine, etc. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:subglacial_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Subglacial setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "Carried upon, deposited from, or pertaining to the top surface of a glacier or ice sheet; said of meltwater streams, till, drift, etc. " (Jackson, 1997, p. 639). Dreimanis (1988, p. 39) recommendation that "supraglacial" supercede "superglacial" is followed. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:supraglacial_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Supraglacial setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Areas adjacent to glacial front dominanted by sediment and water supplied by glacial melting. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:glacial_outwash_plain_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Glacial outwash plain setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A natural underground open space; it generally has a connection to the surface, is large enough for a person to enter, and extends into darkness. The most common type of cave is formed in limestone by dissolution. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:cave
ControlledConcept.name: Cave

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A prograded shore built seaward by waves and currents, and continuous for some distance along the coast. It is characterized by subparallel beach ridges and swales, in places with associated dunes." Glossary of Geology (Jackson, 1997, p. 626). Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004; based on Jackson 1997
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:strandplain_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Strandplain setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Earth surface setting characterized by surface slope angles high enough that gravity alone becomes a significant factor in geomorphic development, as well as base-of-slope areas influenced by hillslope processes. Hillslope activities include creep, sliding, slumping, falling, and other downslope movements caused by slope collapse induced by gravitational influence on earth materials. May be subaerial or subaqueous. Source: NADM SLTTs, 2004; Hawley, J.W., and Parsons, R.B. 1980. Glossary of selected geomorphic and geologic terms. Mimeo. USDA Soil Conservation Service, West National Technical Center, Portland, OR. 30 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:hillslope_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Hillslope setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Geologic environments within the solid Earth. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:earth_interior_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Earth interior setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphism of country rock at the contact of an igneous body. Source: NADM metamorphic rock vocabulary SLTTm1.0, 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:contact_metamorphic_origin
ControlledConcept.name: Contact metamorphic origin

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphism not obviously localized along contacts of igneous bodies; includes burial metamorphism and ocean ridge metamorphism Source: NADM metamorphic rock vocabulary SLTTm1.0, 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:regional_metamorphic_origin
ControlledConcept.name: Regional metamorphic origin

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by temperatures significantly higher that those associated with normal continental geothermal gradient. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:low_pressure_high_temperature_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Low pressure high temperature setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: High pressure environment characterized by geothermal gradient significantly lower than standard continental geotherm; enviornment in which blueschist facies metamorphic rocks form. Typically associated with subduction zones. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:high_pressure_low_temperature_earth_interior_setting
ControlledConcept.name: High pressure low temperature Earth interior setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by pressures characteristic of upper mantle, but indicated by mineral assemblage in crustal composition rocks. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:ultra_high_pressure_crustal_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Ultra high pressure crustal setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous environment close to the Earth's surface, characterized by more rapid cooling than plutonic setting to produce generally fine-grained intrusive igneous rock that is commonly associated with co-magmatic volcanic rocks. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:hypabyssal_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Hypabyssal setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The zone of the Earth below the crust and above the core, which is divided into the Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:mantle
ControlledConcept.name: mantle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: That part of the mantle which lies above a depth of about 660 km and has a density of 3.4 g/cm3 to 4.0 g/cm3 with increasing depth. Similarly, P-wave velocity increases from about 8 to 11 km/sec with depth and Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:upper_mantle
ControlledConcept.name: upper mantle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: That part of the mantle that lies below a depth of about 660 km. With increasing depth, density increases from ~4.4 g/cm3-to ~5.6 g/cm3, and velocity of compressional seismic waves increases from ~10.7 km/s to ~13.7 km/s (Dziewonski and Anderson, 1981). Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lower_mantle
ControlledConcept.name: lower mantle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The outermost layer or shell of the Earth, defined according to various criteria, including seismic velocity, density and composition; that part of the Earth above the Mohorovicic discontinuity, made up of the Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:crust
ControlledConcept.name: crust

ControlledConcept.gml:description: That type of the Earth's crust which underlies the continents and the continental shelves; it is equivalent to the Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:continental_crust
ControlledConcept.name: Continental crust

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Continental crustal setting dominated by non metamorphosed to low greenschist facies metamorphic rocks, and brittle deformation. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:upper_continental_crustal_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Upper continental crustal setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Continental crustal setting characterized by greenschist to upper amphibolite facies metamorphism, plutonic igneous rocks, and ductile deformation. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:middle_continental_crust_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Middle continental crust setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Continental crustal setting characterized by upper amphibolite to granulite facies metamorphism, insitu melting, residual anhydrous metamorphic rocks, and ductile flow of rock bodies. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lower_continental_crust
ControlledConcept.name: Lower continental crust

ControlledConcept.gml:description: That type of the Earth's crust which underlies the ocean basins. The oceanic crust is 5-10 km thick; it has a density of 2.9 g/cm3, and compressional seismic-wave velocities travelling through it at 4-7.2 km/sec. Setting in crust produced by submarine volcanism at a mid ocean ridge. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:oceanic_crust
ControlledConcept.name: oceanic crust

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Oceanic crustal setting dominated by extrusive rocks, abyssal oceanic sediment, with increasing mafic intrusive rock in lower part. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:upper_oceanic_crustal_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Upper oceanic crustal setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Setting characterized by dominantly intrusive mafic rocks, with sheeted dike complexes in upper part and gabbroic to ultramafic intrusive or metamorphic rocks in lower part. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:lower_oceanic_crustal_setting
ControlledConcept.name: Lower oceanic crustal setting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Crust formed in the transition zone between continental and oceanic crust, during the history of continental rifting that culminates in the formation of a new ocean. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:transitional_crust
ControlledConcept.name: Transitional crust

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Material originated outside of the Earth or its atmosphere. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005;
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventEnvironment:200811:extra_terrestrial_origin
ControlledConcept.name: Extra-terrestrial origin
